awd_titl_txt: Groundwater-forest interactions during drought in temperate forests across scales
awd_abstract_narration:
An estimated 3 trillion trees cover 42 million km2 worldwide - equivalent to the combined areas of North and South America. Societies around the globe rely on forests for water supply and provision of food, medicine, and forest products, as well as other recreational, cultural, and aesthetic benefits. Economically, tropical and temperate forests provide ecosystem goods and services totaling an estimated $23.32 trillion/yr worldwide.  Drought - and changes in drought regimes - have the potential to disrupt this provisioning of forest services through reduced forest growth and increased vegetation stress and mortality. Groundwater, when and where available, may buffer specific portions of forest from the consequences of changing drought regimes. Strategies to adapt to drought impacts on forests requires improved understanding and forecasting of patterns, consequences, and feedbacks between drought response and groundwater. The overarching goal of this research is to evaluate groundwater as an ecosystem attribute that alleviates adverse impacts of changing drought regimes on temperate forests. This project will develop a suite of complementary drought detection tools to observe and link tree and forest response to drought, as influenced by groundwater. We will use simulation models to place our measurements in the context of a range of scenarios. This study will help society to better address forest and water resource challenges in the 21st century through dissemination of results to a broad array of stakeholders including researchers, forest and water resource managers, and the public. 

As drought regimes continue to change and impact forests, it is critical to identify and evaluate ecosystem attributes that alleviate drought stress and to develop novel methodologies to monitor drought response. Traditional methods rely on limited water stress observations of individual trees and stand level vegetation metrics derived from coarse resolution satellite images. Synthesis of such data dilutes species-specific responses and does not provide the necessary datasets to reveal mechanisms linking drought impacts on forests across spatial scales. Through the proposed work, multiple lines of evidence will be used to quantify species-specific tree and forest response to drought as buffered by groundwater. Specifically, this research proposes to investigate drought response across gradients of groundwater depth using: (1) tree ring chronologies to provide historic tree response and quantify the influence of groundwater on tree growth and drought vulnerability; (2) tree sway measurements from accelerometers to continuously monitor water stress and tree physiological response to drought; and, (3) hyperspectral remote sensing to spatially map species-specific foliar drought response. These novel methods for monitoring drought response will be aggregated with traditional complementary datasets to develop a suite of numerical models for simulating groundwater-tree interactions to mechanistically represent field observations. This project will provide a basis for understanding the role of groundwater in conferring drought resistance at the tree, transect, and landscape scales in temperate forests.

por.por_cntn:
Groundwater use by forests in humid regions is an ecosystem process that reduces drought vulnerability of trees where groundwater is shallow, but this process is often ignored by researchers and forest, water, and agricultural managers. Demonstrating the importance of groundwater-tree interactions in wetter environments is substantially underrepresented in the ecohydrology literature and is adversely impacting the performance of land surface and climate models, especially in the context of a changing climate. Prior to this project, we lacked quantitative information on the extent and patterns of groundwater influence in the forests of the Upper Midwest and in humid forests in general. This project found up to twice as much tree growth in areas with sandy soils and shallow groundwater coincident with frequent groundwater use by trees (occurs up to 81% of non-rainy summer days). Groundwater’s influence on tree growth and transpiration declined as groundwater deepened along a depth to groundwater gradient 1-5m below land surface. These groundwater-forest interaction processes were scaled along time and space axes. The substantial influence of groundwater use on tree growth was leveraged to reconstruct historic groundwater and lake level histories in these environments, up to a 90-year period. Further, groundwater-forest interactions in humid areas were quantified using satellite imagery, airborne hyperspectral remote sensing and groundwater flow models, and areas were highlighted throughout Wisconsin with low-to-high likelihood of groundwater influence.   

Our research is enabling more targeted and spatially explicit forest and water management that accounts for the buffering effects of shallow groundwater, such as prioritizing drought resistant areas from land use conversion, adaptive planting strategies in drought vulnerable regions, and employing managed aquifer recharge to enhance ecosystem services including improved groundwater supply, increased forest productivity, and support of trout habitat through increased baseflow. This project has filled knowledge gaps on groundwater-tree interactions in humid forests, which have substantially limited our ability to forecast patterns, consequences, and feedbacks between drought response and groundwater systems.

In this project, the development of a novel method using accelerometers to continuously monitor water stress, interception, and canopy evaporation provides researchers with a new tool that addresses the primary short comings of traditional approaches.  First, the accelerometers represent the integrated response at the tree scale and avoid heterogeneity associated with leaf-scale measurements of water potential or point-based measurements of throughfall and interception.  Second, recording of tree sway provides continuous time-series rather leaf-based sampling of water stress which offers point in-time measurements and involves considerable labor costs. Accelerometers are inexpensive and are showing the potential to evaluate ecohydrological processes (or any process that affects biomechanical properties of trees) associated with trees. Adaptation of accelerometer-based methods to video-based methods of monitoring tree sway will expand our monitoring capacity from individual trees to swaths of forest.

The findings from this research have been broadly disseminated to diverse stakeholders throughout Wisconsin as well as to national and international audiences. As part of this project, 1PhD student, 2 MS students, one post-doctoral associate, and 18 undergraduate students received valuable training and education in interdisciplinary research linking the hydrological and ecological sciences.  They gained experience about how such approaches can be used to improve understanding of wholistic management of forest and water resources in ways that enhance overall benefits to society. They have, or are prepared to, embark on careers as water resource engineers, environmental consultants, professionals within governmental/regulatory agencies and as university faculty. The results of this research have been made available through peer-reviewed publications, online databases, and by incorporating these findings into both undergraduate and graduate level courses in geology and hydrology that reach 100s of students each year.
